choices.text: Borderline Lepromatous leprosy

questions.text: Histopathology of a tissue sample from a patient with leprosy is shown below. All the following are possibilities EXCEPT.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tuberculoid leprosy

 

Option A:

 

  • The given image shows a Grenz zone or Band of Unna, which is a band of uninvolved papillary dermis that does not contain granulomas or inflammatory infiltrate.
  • Grenz zone is absent in Tuberculoid leprosy.
  • Dermal granulomas, which are collections of epithelioid cells with giant cells, are seen in tuberculoid leprosy.
  • The granulomas are elongated and typically follow neurovascular bundles, running parallel to the surface. The granulomas extend up to the epidermis, thereby obscuring the Grenz zone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Lepromatous Leprosy –

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy represents the polar opposite of the leprosy spectrum with poor cell-mediated immunity leading to a multibacillary state.
  • Lepromatous leprosy exhibits the Grenz zone most obviously because there are not many granulomas to fill the empty spaces below the epidermis.
  • The Virchow cells with globi as indicated in the image, which are large macrophages filled with mycobacteria, are a characteristic feature of lepromatous leprosy.
  • Additionally, it appears on the borderline spectrum.

 

Option C. Borderline Leprosy –

 

  • Borderline leprosy falls within the middle of the leprosy spectrum, with histological features that can fluctuate between those seen in tuberculoid and lepromatous forms.
  • It can show a grenz zone and foamy macrophages, which makes it a possibility in this case.

 

Option D. Borderline Lepromatous leprosy –

 

  • Borderline Lepromatous leprosy is a subtype of leprosy that falls between the lepromatous and tuberculoid forms.
  • It would show features of both, with numerous bacteria present as well as some immune response limiting the spread.
  • Therefore, the histological findings seen in the image could correspond to this type, making it a possible option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The absence of a grenz zone in histopathological samples is associated with tuberculoid leprosy, while the presence of a grenz zone and Virchow cells with globi are indicative of lepromatous forms of the disease.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Page No. 28.5

choices.text: Multibacillary Leprosy cases need treatment with Multi Drug Therapy (MDT) for 12 Months
Dapsone acts as Anti Leprosy Medication by Inhibiting Folate Synthesis.
Lepromin Testing is used for Diagnosis of Leprosy
Clofazimine causes Deposition of Crystals in Intestinal Mucosa

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements regarding management of Leprosy EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lepromin Testing is used for Diagnosis of Leprosy

 

Option C:

 

  • Lepromin test is useful to classify the lesions of leprosy patients, to assess the prognosis & response to treatment, to assess the resistance of individuals to leprosy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Multibacillary leprosy cases need treatment with Multi Drug Therapy (MDT) for 12 months.

 

Revised Treatment Regimen of Leprosy:

Same Drug Dosages and Regimens for both Paucibacillary Leprsoy & Multibacillary Leprosy except Duration ; Paucibacillary Leprosy for 6 months & Multibacillary Leprosy for 12 months.

Option B. Dapsone:

 

  • Dapsone (DDS) has good oral absorption, is weakly bactericidal due to the inhibition of dihydropteroate synthase, which inhibits folate synthesis.
  • It is a part of multidrug therapy for leprosy.
  • Adverse effects of Dapsone are:
  1. Hemolysis & anemia
  2. Psychosis
  3. DDS syndrome or 5-week dermatitis- occurs 5-6 weeks after starting dapsone, which presents with:
  • Erythroderma
  • Hepatosplenomegaly
  • Lymphadenopathy
  • Fever
  • Hepatitis

 

Option D. Clofazimine:

 

  • It has a weak bactericidal activity against mycobacterium leprae & causes deposition of crystals in intestinal mucosa, liver, lymph nodes & spleen.
  • Other adverse effects of Clofazimine are:
    • Icthyosis of skin.
    • Skin discoloration (red to purple black)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lepromin test is used to assess the type of immune response in leprosy and is not a diagnostic test, while Multi Drug Therapy for 12 months, the mechanism of action of dapsone, and the side effects of clofazimine are important aspects of leprosy management.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 28 Page No. 28.1- 28.15

choices.text: Type 1 Lepra Reaction presents with new Red Painful Lesions
Systemic Symptoms are a feature of Type 2 Lepra Reaction
Type 2 Lepra Reaction is due to Immune Complex Deposition
Steroids are Drug of Choice in both Type 1 & 2 Lepra Reactions

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements regarding Reactions in leprosy EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Type 1 Lepra Reaction presents with New Red Painful Lesions

 

Explanation:

 

  • Type 2 lepra reaction is associated with Type III hypersensitivity reaction (Immune complex deposition) & clinically it presents with new red painful lesions, and also systemic features like fever, arthralgias, anorexia, keratitis, iritis, nephritis, synovitis, orchitis.

 

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In leprosy, Type 1 reactions involve inflammation of existing lesions rather than the appearance of new lesions, while Type 2 reactions may present with systemic symptoms and are related to immune complex deposition, with steroids being the treatment of choice for both types of reactions.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology 9th Edition Chapter 28 Page No. 28.1- 28.16

questions.text:
Which diagnostic investigation is utilized to identify the condition characterized by a 40-year-old man displaying abrupt Erythematous Painful Lesions on the Trunk and Face, Joint Pain, and Glove and Stock Anesthesia?

 

1. Nerve examination

2. Skin biopsy

3. Slit skin smear

4. Mantoux test
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2, 3

 

Explanation:

 

  • The clinical scenario points to a case of leprosy. The diagnosis of this condition requires nerve examination, skin biopsy, and a slit skin smear (Option B - 1, 2, 3).

  • The clinical presentation described suggests a condition called leprosy or Hansen's disease, which can cause skin lesions, nerve damage resulting in anaesthesia, and joint pain.

  1. Nerve examination - An essential part of the diagnosis of leprosy involves the examination of nerves for enlargement and tenderness, which can indicate nerve damage due to the disease.

  2. Skin biopsy - A biopsy of the affected skin can be taken and histologically examined for the presence of Mycobacterium leprae, the bacterium that causes leprosy.

  3. Slit skin smear - This test involves taking a sample from the skin (usually from the ear lobes or from lesions) and staining it for acid-fast bacilli, which is a characteristic of Mycobacterium leprae.

 

The Mantoux Test (Option 4)

 

  • The Mantoux test is used to diagnose tuberculosis, not leprosy.

  • It involves the Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) to detect Mycobacterium Tuberculosis Infection.

  • Mycobacterium Tuberculosis and Mycobacterium Leprae are both acid-fast Bacilli.

  • The Mantoux test is specific for TB and does not directly aid in the diagnosis of leprosy

 

Characteristic clinical features of Hansenâ€™s Disease / Leprosy

 

  • Mycobacterium leprae is the cause of the chronic granulomatous disease known as leprosy.

  • The typical incubation period for leprosy is 2 to 12 years.

  • It frequently manifests as a visible skin lesion, such as a hypopigmented or erythematous macule, or as a numb spot on the skin.

  • The face, buttocks, trunk, and extensor aspects of the limbs are frequently affected by lesions.

  • Skin, cutaneous, and peripheral nerves, as well as mucous membranes, are all impacted.

  • The Ulnar nerve followed by the posterior tibial nerve, median and lateral popliteal nerves, are the peripheral nerves that are most frequently affected.

  • The facial nerve is the cranial nerve that is involved most frequently.

  • Both nerve function and hair growth are compromised by the lesions.

  • Burns or ulcers on the amputation limb may also be present in the patients.

 

Classification Systems of Leprosy:

 

  • Ridley-Jopling Classification

    • Tuberculoid (TT)

    • Borderline tubercular (BT)

    • Borderline (BB)

    • Borderline lepromatous (BL)

    • Lepromatous (LL)

 

  • WHO Classification:

    • Paucibacillary

    • Multibacillary

 

Cardinal Signs for the Diagnosis of Leprosy:

 

 

  • The presence of two of the three signs can establish the diagnosis of leprosy.

  • Other tests done for diagnosis of leprosy include nerve biopsy in pure neural leprosy and PGL-1 antibody in cases with low bacterial load.

  • Mantoux test is not useful in diagnosis of leprosy. This is the test which helps to explain the prognosis of leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The appropriate diagnostic investigations for a suspected case of leprosy include nerve examination, skin biopsy, and slit skin smear to detect the presence of Mycobacterium leprae and to assess the extent of nerve damage.

 

Ref: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 28 Page No 28.1, 28.3, 28.12

Harrisons Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition 1385, 1386, 1388

choices.text: Stop MDT and Start Oral Steroids
Continue MDT and Add Oral Steroids

questions.text: In a pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation, who is currently undergoing multidrug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, she now presents with type 2 lepra reaction. What is the preferred treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue MDT and Add Oral Steroids

 

Option D:

 

  • In the management of leprosy, it is crucial to continue Multi Drug Therapy (MDT) to effectively treat the underlying infection caused by Mycobacterium Leprae.
  • A Type 2 lepra reaction, also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL), is a complex immunological reaction that occurs in Lepromatous and Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy, which can present with Painful Nodules, Fever, Malaise, and other Systemic symptoms.
  • Oral Steroids, such as Prednisone, are the treatment of choice for controlling Acute Inflammatory Complications associated with Type 2 Lepra Reaction. They help Reduce Inflammation and Immune response.
  • It is important to manage the reaction without discontinuing the MDT to prevent the development of Drug Resistance and further progression of the disease.

 

Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL)

 

  • It is a type 3 hypersensitive immune complex-mediated reaction that affects the skin, nerves, and other organs.
  • It is typically recurrent and commonly observed in individuals with multibacillary leprosy. ENL may occur before treatment, during treatment or after completion of treatment.
  • It is characterized by painful, erythematous nodules appearing on the extensor surfaces of the limbs and face.
  • In a type 2 lepra reaction, systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and the appearance of fresh skin lesions can be observed.

 

Treatment includes:

 

  • High doses of glucocorticoids are frequently administered to all patients which assist in reducing the acute signs and symptoms of inflammation.
  • In patients with lepra reactions, MDT is never discontinued.
  • Only severe cases of type-2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum Leprosum are treated with thalidomide. Thalidomide is gold standard for type II Lepra reaction, but it is NOT the Drug of Choice due to its cost factor & also its Adverse drug reactions profile.

 

Type I & II Lepra Reactions (ENL= Erythema Nodosum Leprosum):

 

 

  • To manage a pregnant woman experiencing a type 2 lepra reaction, it is essential to continue the multidrug therapy (MDT) while adding oral steroids as an additional treatment.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Stop MDT and start oral steroids:

 

  • Stopping MDT is not advisable because it can lead to the proliferation of Mycobacterium leprae and risk the development of drug resistance.

 

Option B. Antibiotics:

 

  • While antibiotics are a part of MDT to treat the bacterial infection, they alone are not sufficient to address the acute inflammatory symptoms of a Type 2 lepra reaction.

 

Option C. Thalidomide:

 

  • Thalidomide is an effective treatment for Type 2 lepra reactions due to its potent anti-inflammatory properties.
  • However, it is absolutely contraindicated in pregnant women due to its teratogenic effects, which can cause severe birth defects as seen in the below image.

 

 

Phocomelia

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In a pregnant woman with leprosy who presents with a Type 2 lepra reaction, the preferred treatment is to continue multidrug therapy and add oral steroids to manage the acute inflammatory symptoms.
  • Thalidomide is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenicity.

 

Ref:  Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page No 28.16

Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine 21st Edition Page No 1387, 1390

choices.text: Stop MDT give Thalidomide
Continue MDT, Start Thalidomide
Stop MDT, Start Systemic Corticosteroids
Continue MDT, Start Systemic Steroids

questions.text: In a case where a patient undergoing Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) experiences a deterioration of existing lesions and nerve complications, what course of action would you consider taking next?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Continue MDT, Start Systemic Steroids

 

Option D:

 

  • This is the correct management for a leprosy patient with nerve damage, which is likely due to an immune reaction called a leprosy reaction. Systemic corticosteroids are used to control the inflammation and prevent further nerve damage.
  • MDT should be continued to treat the underlying infection.
  • The reason for selecting option D is that systemic corticosteroids are effective in treating acute nerve inflammation and can prevent further damage while continuing MDT ensures that the infection is adequately treated.

 

The situation described, where pre-existing lesions worsen during multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, indicates a type 1 lepra reaction. In managing this condition, the recommended approach would be to continue MDT while initiating systemic steroid treatment.

 

  • Type 1 lepra reactions are marked by inflammation of existing skin lesions, leading to symptoms such as edema, redness, and pain. While ulcers are uncommon, the development of new lesions is exceptionally rare. Additionally, acute neuritis may occur, presenting with tenderness and impairment of both motor and sensory functions.
  • In patients with lepra reactions, MDT is never discontinued. NSAIDs and oral steroids can be added to treat pain.
  • Thalidomide is considered the gold standard for treating severe cases of type-2 lepra reaction or erythema nodosum leprosum. However, it is not the Drug of Choice due to its high cost and potential for adverse drug reactions. In type II lepra reactions, patients may experience systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and the appearance of new skin lesions.

 

Type I & II Lepra Reactions:

 

 

(ENL = Erythema Nodosum Leprosum)

 

Explanation:

           

Option A. Stop MDT give thalidomide.

 

  • Thalidomide is an immunomodulatory drug that may be used in certain conditions, like leprosy and its complications.
  • However, stopping MDT is not recommended as it is crucial to continue the treatment of the primary disease. Thalidomide is not used as treatment for Type 1 lepra reaction in leprosy.

 

Option B. Continue MDT, start thalidomide –

 

  • While MDT should be continued, thalidomide is not typically used for nerve complications.
  • It's used primarily for severe or recurrent erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) Type 2 Lepra eaction, which is an immune-mediated complication of leprosy.

 

Option C. Stop MDT, start systemic corticosteroids –

 

  • Stopping MDT is not advised as the antibiotics in MDT are essential for treating the bacterial infection causing the disease.
  • The MDT should be continued to prevent the development of drug resistance and to adequately treat the underlying infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the case of nerve complications in a patient undergoing multi-drug therapy for conditions like leprosy, the appropriate course of action is to continue the anti-microbial therapy and start systemic steroids to manage the inflammatory reaction causing nerve damage.

 

Ref: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology -9th Edition Chapter 28 Page No 28.5, 28.12, 28.16

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents to the outpatient department with a satellite skin lesion. On examination, the patient has one hypopigmented lesion and one thickened nerve. The images of two blister packs are provided. Based on the WHO / NLEP Guidelines, which treatment is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
The correct answer is B. Packet 2 for 12 months.

Explanation:

Latest Guidelines for Leprosy: NLEP = WHO (from April 1, 2025)

As of April 1, 2025, India's NLEP has aligned completely with WHO guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of leprosy. This means that the same criteria and drug regimens are now followed globally and in India.

 

*If a case has any one of the three features suggestive of MB, he/she is classified as MB.

 

Treatment Regimen: WHO & NLEP (Post April 1st 2025)

 

 

Other Options:

Option A: Packet 1 for 12 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option C: Packet 1 for 6 months: 

This packet was used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy according to old guidelines of NLEP, which is not suitable for a patient with multibacillary leprosy.

Option D Packet 2 for 6 months: 

Although Packet 2 contains the correct medications, the treatment duration of 6 months is insufficient for multibacillary leprosy according to WHO guidelines, which recommends 12 months.

 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to diagnose Leprosy 

 

OLD NLEP GUIDELINES to treat Leprosy 

 

Educational objective:

  • As of April 1, 2025, NLEP follows WHO guidelines for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • Classification is based on skin lesions, nerve involvement, and skin smear.
  • For a patient with multibacillary leprosy, characterized by one or more thickened nerves and multiple skin lesions, the appropriate treatment is with a regimen containing rifampicin, clofazimine, and dapsone (Packet 2) for a duration of 12 months.

 

References:

Joplingâ€™s handbook of leprosy, 6th edition, page no 10

Andrewâ€™s diseases of the skin: clinical dermatology 13th edition page no 338, 339, 345

questions.text:
Chemoprophylaxis for Leprosy should be given to which of the following persons?

 

  1. Sharing the Same Clothes, Towels
  2. Living with a patient with Leprosy for > 6 Month
  3. Contact of Age more than 2 Years
  4. Contact for more than 20 Hours per Week.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

 

  • Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to contacts 2, 3 and 4.

 

Chemoprophylaxis for leprosy should be given to the following contacts:

 

  • Being identified as a contact, i.e., a person who has been in close contact with the index case for 20 hours (option 4) or more per week for more than 3 months (Option 2) (Exception is blanket approach where no link with an index case needs to be established.)
  • Age: More than 2 years (Option 3); if younger than 2 years, the child can be given SDR at the age of 2, in follow-up visits of contacts (if meeting all other inclusion criteria.)
  • Consent of the contact obtained. Depending on the country situation, this can be written or verbal consent. In the case of children, consent should be obtained from the parent or guardian, and sometimes an assent from the grown-up children.
  • Sharing the same clothes and towels, while a potential route of transmission, is not generally considered a primary criterion for chemoprophylaxis.

 

Rifampicin:

  • A single dose of 600 mg kills more than 99% of the susceptible organisms present at the start of treatment, that is as much as 3 to 6 months of daily treatment with the combination dapsone plus Clofazimine.
  • Rifampicin has become established as a highly potent bactericidal drug, and it acts by inhibiting the bacterial DNA dependent RNA polymerase.
  • Single Dose of Rifampicin (SDR) is used in chemoprophylaxis.
  • Chemoprophylaxis must be initiated only 4 weeks after treatment for leprosy has begun in the patientto ensure the patient is non-infectious.

 

 

Educational Objective 

Exclusion Criteria

  • Persons with possible signs and/or symptoms of Leprosy.
  • Persons with possible signs and/or symptoms of TB or Confirmed with TB.
  • Persons with a history of Liver or Kidney Disorders.
  • Pregnancy; SDR can be given after the delivery.
  • Persons who have received Rifampicin in the last two years e.g. as treatment of TB, leprosy or as prophylaxis (e.g. contact of another index case).
  • Persons with history of Allergy to Rifampicin.
  • Refusal to take SDR.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page no 242

Leprosy/Hansen disease: Contact Tracing and Post-Exposure ;Prophylaxis

questions.text: Dapsone syndrome in Hansen disease treatment is seen after how many weeks of therapy initiation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 5 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

  • Dapsone syndrome, also known as "five-week dermatitis," usually occurs five to six weeks after the initiation of dapsone treatment in Hansen's disease (leprosy).
  • It is characterized by symptoms such as erythroderma, generalized lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, fever, and hepatitis, and typically subsides upon cessation of the drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Dapsone syndrome, a hypersensitivity reaction characterized by a range of symptoms including erythroderma and hepatosplenomegaly, typically occurs about five to six weeks after the initiation of dapsone therapy in the treatment of Hansen's disease.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page No 245

choices.text: It is used to define the Immune Status of the patient.
It is a Diagnostic Test.
It is a Cell-Mediated Response.
It may be used for Prognosis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a suspected case of leprosy undergoes a lepromin skin test. The test is administered to assess the patient's type of leprosy and potential response to treatment. Which of the following statements is INCORRECT regarding the lepromin test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It is a Diagnostic Test

 

Option B.

 

  • The lepromin test is not used for the diagnosis of leprosy, as it does not differentiate between those infected and those who are not.
  • It is used primarily for prognosis and to determine the type of immune response

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. It is used to define the immune status of the patient:

 

  • The lepromin test is used to determine the patient's immune response to Mycobacterium leprae.
  • A positive test suggests a good cell-mediated immune response, typically seen in tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Option C. It is a cell-mediated response:

 

  • The lepromin test measures a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, which is a cell-mediated immune response to the antigens of Mycobacterium leprae.

 

Option D. It may be used for prognosis:

 

  • A positive lepromin test generally indicates a better prognosis and is associated with a stronger cell-mediated immune response, which is typical of tuberculoid leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The lepromin test is used to assess the immune status of a patient with leprosy and is not a diagnostic test.
  • It measures the cell-mediated immune response and can provide prognostic information, with a positive test indicating a better prognosis.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page No 11

questions.text: A 12-year-old child presented with multiple hypopigmented patches on back & lower limb. On examination the patches were hypo aesthetic & bilateral ulnar and lateral popliteal nerves were enlarged. Which of the following drugs and their dosages are to be given on Day 1 of supervised drug administration according to National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) Guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rifampicin 450 mg Clofazimine 150 mg Dapsone 50 mg

 

Option A.

 

Latest Guidelines for Leprosy: NLEP = WHO (from April 1, 2025)

As of April 1, 2025, India's NLEP has aligned completely with WHO guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of leprosy. This means that the same criteria and drug regimens are now followed globally and in India.

 

  • A 12-year-old child presenting with multiple hypopigmented and hypo aesthetic patches with bilateral ulnar and popliteal nerves enlarged clinches the diagnosis of Multi Bacillary Leprosy

  • Hence treatment would be with MB MDT regimen according to NLEP Guidelines

 

Explanation:

 

  • According to the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP) Guidelines, for a child aged 9-14 years, the Day 1 supervised dose of medication for Multi-Bacillary (MB) leprosy includes Rifampicin 450 mg, Clofazimine 150 mg, and Dapsone 50 mg.

 

 

Option B. Rifampicin 600 mg Clofazimine 300 mg Dapsone 100 mg:

 

  • Incorrect because this dosage is for adults with MB leprosy, not for children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct dosages of multi-drug therapy for a child with Multi-Bacillary (MB) leprosy on Day 1 of supervised treatment according to NLEP Guidelines, which for a child aged 9-14 years includes Rifampicin 450 mg, Clofazimine 150 mg, and Dapsone 50 mg.

 

Ref: Joplingâ€™s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page No 252

choices.text: Erythema Nodosum Leprosum
Lucio Phenomenon

questions.text: A patient of leprosy on multidrug treatment came to OPD after 5 weeks of treatment with rash over the body. On examination he has high grade fever, jaundice, and an itchy rash all over the body. There was no evidence of any red tender nodules over the extremities or elsewhere over the body. What is the likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapsone Hypersensitivity Syndrome

 

Option A: Dapsone Hypersensitivity Syndrome:

 

  • Dapsone Hypersensitivity syndrome is a severe idiosyncratic reaction that typically occurs about 5 weeks after the initiation of therapy.
  • It presents with fever, rash (usually maculopapular), lymphadenopathy, and systemic symptoms such as hepatitis, which may manifest as jaundice.
  • This condition is dose-independent and requires immediate cessation of dapsone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL):

 

  • ENL, or Type II lepra reaction, presents with tender red nodules, systemic involvement like fever, malaise, and enlarged tender nerves.

 

 

  

 

 

  • The absence of red tender nodules and nerve tenderness makes ENL less likely in this case.
     

Option C. Lucio phenomenon:

 

  • Lucio phenomenon is a rare reaction seen in diffuse lepromatous leprosy presenting with painful erythematous plaques, typically on the extremities, that can progress to necrosis and ulceration.
  • It does not typically present with a generalized itchy rash or jaundice.


Option D. Reversal reaction (Type I reaction):

 

  • Reversal reaction is characterized by the acute inflammation of pre-existing leprosy skin lesions and nerve enlargement without systemic symptoms like fever or jaundice.
  • The pruritic rash and systemic symptoms described are not typical of a reversal reaction.


Educational Objective:

 

  • Dapsone Hypersensitivity syndrome in a leprosy patient who presents with fever, jaundice, and a widespread itchy rash without tender nodules or nerve enlargement, approximately 5 weeks after starting multidrug therapy. This serious reaction requires immediate attention and discontinuation of dapsone.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 30 Page No 442

choices.text: 3 Drugs are given in the regimen
Treatment Duration is 18 Months
Treatment should be Completed in 18 Months

questions.text: Identify the INCORRECT statement regarding Treatment of a Multi Bacillary Leprosy patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Treatment Duration is 18 Months

 

Option B:

 

  • According to the updated guidelines by the National Leprosy Eradication Programme (NLEP), which recommend a treatment duration of 12 months for multi-bacillary leprosy, not 18 months.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. 3 drugs are given in the regimen:

 

  • The Standard Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) regimen for multi-bacillary (MB) leprosy involves a combination of three drugs: Rifampicin, Dapsone, and Clofazimine.
     


Option C. Treatment should be completed in 18 months:

 

  • NLEP guidelines stipulate a 12-month treatment course for MB leprosy.
  • This course can be completed in 18 months, otherwise patient is termed as Defaulter
     

Option D. Follow up period is 24 months:

 

  • The follow-up period after the completion of treatment for MB leprosy is typically 24 months to monitor for any signs of relapse or late reactions.


Educational Objective:

 

  • The treatment duration for multi-bacillary leprosy according to NLEP guidelines is 12 months, not 18 months, with a follow-up period of 24 months post-treatment to ensure there are no relapses or complications.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page No 252

questions.text: Foam Cells are seen in Abundance in which type of Leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepromatous leprosy (LL)

 

Option B:

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy is characterized by numerous foam cells, also known as Virchow's cells, which are lipid-laden macrophages filled with Mycobacterium leprae.
     

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Borderline lepromatous (BL):

 

  • BL leprosy can have foam cells, they are most abundant in LL leprosy where there is widespread infiltration of the skin with numerous bacilli.

 

Option C. Pure Neuritic Leprosy:

 

  • Pure Neuritic Leprosy primarily affects nerves, and foam cells are more typically associated with cutaneous lesions.

 

Option D. Borderline (BB):

 

  • In BB leprosy, foam cells may be present but are not as prominent as in LL leprosy.
  • BB leprosy has features between tuberculoid and lepromatous leprosy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lepromatous leprosy (LL) is the form of Hansen's disease most associated with the presence of abundant foam cells, which are macrophages filled with undigested M. leprae.
  • These foam cells are indicative of the multibacillary form of the disease and are used as a diagnostic histopathological feature.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page No 123

questions.text: Which of the following medications is used only for treating patients with Type II Lepra reaction but NOT used in Type I Lepra reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Thalidomide

 

Option D:

 

  • Thalidomide is particularly effective in treating Type II lepra reactions, also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL), due to its potent Anti-Inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects.
  • It is not used for Type I reactions, which are managed with steroids and other immunosuppressive agents.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Steroids:

 

  • Steroids are used in the management of both Type I and Type II lepra reactions. They are effective in reducing inflammation and immune reactions in both types of reactions.

 

Option B. Azathioprine:

 

  • Azathioprine may be used as a steroid-sparing agent in the treatment of both Type I and Type II lepra reactions, although it is not the first-line treatment for either.

 

Option C. Chloroquine:

 

  • Chloroquine, an antimalarial medication, has been used in the treatment of Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL), which is a Type II reaction, but it is also used for Type I reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thalidomide is uniquely used for Type II lepra reactions (erythema nodosum leprosum) and is not indicated for Type I lepra reactions.
  • Thalidomide's effectiveness is based on its ability to inhibit TNF-alpha, a cytokine involved in the inflammatory process of ENL.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page No 217

questions.text: What is the predominant Histological finding in a patient who has Tuberculoid leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Granulomas

 

Option B:

 

  • The predominant histopathological finding in tuberculoid leprosy is well-formed granulomas.
     

 

  • Granulomas consist of Lymphocytes, Epithelioid cells, and Langhan’s giant cells.
  • These granulomas consist of collections of immune cells that form as a response to the presence of Mycobacterium leprae, indicative of a robust immune response.


Explanation:

 

Option A. Foam Cells:

 

  • Foam cells, or Virchow's cells, are typically found in lepromatous leprosy, not tuberculoid leprosy.


Option C. Caseous Necrosis:

 

  • Caseous necrosis is a characteristic feature of tuberculosis, not leprosy.
  • In leprosy, especially the tuberculoid form, granulomas are predominantly seen and caseous necrosis is only seen with Nerve granulomas.


Option D. Acantholysis:

 

  • Acantholysis refers to the loss of connections between keratinocytes in the epidermis and is seen in conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris, not in leprosy.


Educational Objective:

 

  • Granulomas is the predominant histopathological feature in tuberculoid leprosy, reflecting a strong cell-mediated immune response that contains the infection and prevents widespread dissemination.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 14 Page No 136

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE in relation to Type 2 Lepra Reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Underlying Pathogenesis is Increased Cell Mediated Immunity.

 

Option C:

 

  • The pathogenesis of Type 2 Lepra Reaction (ENL) is primarily due to immune complex deposition(Type III hypersensitivity reaction) and not increased cell-mediated immunity, which is more characteristic of Type 1 reactions.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Seen in Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy and Lepromatous Leprosy patients:

 

  • Type 2 Lepra Reaction, also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL), is typically seen in patients with Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy and Lepromatous Leprosy, which are at the multibacillary end of the leprosy spectrum.

 

Option B. MDT should be continued, and Steroids are to be added:

 

  • During a Type 2 reaction, the mainstay treatment includes the continuation of Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) for leprosy along with the addition of steroids to manage the inflammatory reaction.

 

Option D. Patients present with High grade fever, Red Tender nodules over body:

 

  • The clinical presentation of ENL includes systemic symptoms such as high-grade fever and red tender nodules, known as erythema nodosum leprosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type 2 Lepra Reaction (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum) is associated with immune complex deposition rather than increased cell-mediated immunity.
  • It presents with systemic symptoms and cutaneous manifestations requiring the continuation of MDT and the addition of anti-inflammatory treatment, typically steroids.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 29 Page No 424

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presented multiple hypopigmented patches all over the body which are distributed almost symmetrically. On examination multiple thickened nerves almost symmetrically enlarged are palpable. What type of leprosy does the patient has?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Borderline Lepromatous

 

Option B:

 

  • The presence of almost symmetrically distributed hypopigmented skin patches over body and multiple thickened nerves almost symmetrically enlarged suggests Borderline Lepromatous leprosy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pure Neuritic:

 

  • Pure Neuritic leprosy presents with nerve involvement without the skin lesions, which is not the case in the scenario described.

 

Option C. Borderline tuberculoid:

 

  • Borderline tuberculoid leprosy would typically present with fewer and asymmetric skin lesions, and while nerve involvement is common, it does not typically present with symmetry as described.

 

Option D. Indeterminate:

 

  • Indeterminate leprosy is an early and unstable form, often presenting as a single or a few hypopigmented macules without definite nerve enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Borderline Lepromatous leprosy as a type characterized by multiple almost symmetrically distributed skin lesions and multiple thickened nerves almost symmetrically enlarged.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 15 Page No 244

choices.text: Useful in Type 2 Lepra Reaction
Also Useful in Type 1 Lepra Reaction

questions.text: Identify the FALSE statement among the following options in relation to Thalidomide in the treatment of leprosy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Also Useful in Type 1 Lepra reaction

 

Option D:

 

  • Thalidomide is not typically used in the treatment of Type 1 Lepra reactions, also known as reversal reactions, which are managed with steroids and other immunosuppressive therapies.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Teratogenic drug:

 

  • Thalidomide is highly teratogenic and can cause severe birth defects, which is why its use is highly regulated and contraindicated during pregnancy.

 

Option B. Causes Peripheral neuropathy:

 

  • A known side effect of thalidomide is peripheral neuropathy, which can be a significant complication requiring monitoring during treatment.

 

Option C. Useful in Type 2 Lepra reaction:

 

  • Thalidomide is particularly effective in treating Type 2 Lepra Reactions, also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL), due to its Anti-Inflammatory Properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Thalidomide is a Teratogenic Drug used in the treatment of Type 2 Lepra Reactions (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum) and can cause peripheral neuropathy as a side effect, but it is not used for Type 1 Lepra reactions.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 30 Page No 472

questions.text: Which among the following medications can cause orange discolouration of urine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rifampicin

 

Option C:

 

  • Rifampicin can cause orange-red discoloration of bodily fluids, including urine, feces, sweat, saliva, and tears. This is a benign and well-recognized side effect of the medication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dapsone:

 

  • Dapsone does not typically cause orange discoloration of bodily fluids.
  • It can cause hemolysis and methemoglobinemia as side effects, especially in patients with Glucose-6-Phosphate Dehydrogenase (G6PD) Deficiency.

 

Option B. Thalidomide:

 

  • Thalidomide does not cause orange discoloration of urine; its significant side effects include teratogenicity and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Option D. Clofazimine:

 

  • Clofazimine can cause skin and bodily fluids to turn pink to brownish black, but it is not typically associated with orange discoloration of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rifampicin can cause orange-red discoloration of bodily fluids, including urine, which is a harmless side effect and does not indicate harm or the need to stop therapy.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 30 Page No 442

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with inflammatory manifestations of Erythema Nodosum Leprosum?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tumour Necrosis Factor Alpha (TNF-α):

 

Option A:

 

  • TNF-α is a cytokine that plays a key role in the pathogenesis of Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL), an immune-mediated complication of leprosy.
  • TNF-α is associated with the inflammatory cascade that leads to the formation of the painful nodules characteristic of ENL.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Interferon Gamma (IFNâ€γ):

 

  • While IFN-γ is a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in the immune response against Mycobacterium leprae, it is not specifically implicated in the pathogenesis of ENL as prominently as TNF-α.

 

Option C. Interleukin 10 (IL-10):

 

  • IL-10 is an anti-inflammatory cytokine, and while it plays a role in the immune response, it is not primarily responsible for the inflammatory manifestations seen in ENL.

 

Option D. Transforming growth factor beta (TGF -β):

 

  • TGF-β is generally considered an anti-inflammatory and regulatory cytokine and is not typically associated with the inflammatory symptoms of ENL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tumour Necrosis Factor Alpha (TNF-α) is the cytokine closely associated with the inflammatory manifestations of Erythema Nodosum Leprosum in leprosy, and management often includes medications that modulate the activity of TNF-α.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page No 220

questions.text: Which among the following is a anti tubercular medication which is also a most potent anti leprotic drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rifampicin

 

Option B:

 

  • Rifampicin is not only an important drug for treating tuberculosis, but it is also considered the most potent anti-leprotic medication.
  • It is an essential component of the Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) for leprosy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Isoniazid:

 

  • While isoniazid is a key component of the anti-tubercular regimen, it is not the most potent drug against Mycobacterium leprae, the causative agent of leprosy.

 

Option C. Ethambutol:

 

  • Ethambutol is used as part of the treatment for tuberculosis, but it does not have the same level of potency against Mycobacterium leprae as rifampicin.

 

Option D. Ofloxacin:

 

  • Ofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that can be used in the treatment of leprosy, particularly in cases of drug resistance.
  • However, it is not as potent as rifampicin in the anti-leprotic regimen.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rifampicin is the most potent anti-leprotic drug that is also used in the treatment of tuberculosis.
  • It is a corner stone drug in the Multi-Drug Therapy (MDT) for leprosy due to its bactericidal action against Mycobacterium leprae.

 

Ref: IAL Textbook of Leprosy, 2nd Edition Chapter 31 Page No 449

questions.text: Which among the following is a anti leprotic drug which is also useful in treatment of Type 2 lepra reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clofazimine

 

Option C:

 

  • Clofazimine has both anti-leprotic and anti-inflammatory properties.
  • It is used in the treatment of leprosy and has a role in managing Type 2 lepra reactions due to its ability to reduce inflammation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Rifampicin

 

  • While rifampicin is a potent anti-leprotic drug used in multi-drug therapy (MDT) for leprosy, it is not specifically used for the treatment of Type 2 lepra reaction (Erythema Nodosum Leprosum, ENL).

 

Option B. Dapsone:

 

  • Dapsone is an anti-leprotic drug used in MDT for leprosy, but it is not the treatment of choice for Type 2 lepra reactions.
  • It is mainly used for its antibacterial effects against Mycobacterium leprae.

 

Option D. Ofloxacin:

 

  • Ofloxacin is used as a second-line agent for the treatment of leprosy, particularly in cases of drug resistance.
  • However, it is not typically used for the treatment of Type 2 lepra reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clofazimine is an anti-leprotic medication that is also beneficial in the treatment of Type 2 lepra reactions due to its anti-inflammatory effects, in addition to its role in the multi-drug therapy for leprosy.

 

Ref: Jopling’s Handbook of Leprosy 6th Edition Page No 211
